results.title: Superfly
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Sig Shore and Gordon Parks Jr
results.brief_description: In the early seventies, mirroring the influential defiant culture of the Black Panthers there developed a uniquely “black” cinema in the United States. Featuring gritty street-wise characters, funk music and liberal doses of sex and violence, this genre quickly developed the name “blaxploitation” - a cinema directed to, and for, largely urban Afro-American audiences. Gordon Parks Jr’s “Superfly” is one of the most important films of the genre, as it unapologetically refused to compromise to white audience expectations. The hero, Priest, is a tough pimp and drug trafficker, who snorts cocaine throughout the movie and has little time for white people and their rules. The film follows his misadventures as he attempts to go straight in a world where the straights don’t want him. With limited resources, Parks Jr manages to create a highly entertaining and fast-paced thriller, fuelled by a brutal lead performance by Ron O’Neal and a stunning score by soul and funk musician, Curtis Mayfield.

results.title: Superfluous people
results.brief_description: A grim and unremitting survey of New York citizens exiled at the margins of capitalist society including the elderly displaced by new housing construction; a woman on relief whose husband was recently released from a mental institution; and those who live in the slums of New York. A document of its time, the film describes the challenge confronting the progressive social aspirations of the Kennedy era. Tough, touching and uncompromising, this is a fascinating documentary with some acute insights into contemporary civilisation.

results.title: Superfluid helium
results.creator_credit: University of St Andrews and Jack F. Allen
results.brief_description: Discusses the various dramatic properties of superfluid helium. Also explains why these properties occur as well as why the term superfluid is used.

results.title: Superb lyrebird
results.brief_description: This synchronised picture and sound record of the territorial calls and display of the lyrebird was produced to help the Division of Wildlife Research to correlate the bird’s throat and beak movements with the sound produced.

results.title: Super size me
results.creator_credit: Roadside Attractions, Samuel Goldwyn Films, Showtime Independent, Morgan Spurlock and The Con
results.brief_description: Eating nothing but McDonald’s for one month, Morgan Spurlock discovers the effects of fast-food first-hand. Under medical supervision, he proves by his experiment that junk food does make you sick - and while it is a bit extreme to eat “Maccas” three meals a day, the film shows how American society is making itself unwell by eating fast food in great amounts and that obesity is one of the largest causes of illness and death in the country. The “Super Size” refers to the larger sizes on offer and Morgan makes the rule that when offered a Super Size he must eat it! Winner of Best Director 2004 Sundance Film Festival.

results.title: Super Boats
results.brief_description: Come sailing on a worldwide, whirlwing adventure as Beyond 2000 examines the future of life on the ocean waves. A dinghy that flies, the world’s first water-jet propelled private luxury ocean cruiser, and windweapon - a cross between a windsurfer and a hang glider are just three of the amazing discoveries.

results.title: Super 8 soldiers
results.creator_credit: Kino Eye Pictures, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Mark Worth
results.brief_description: This unusual video explores the day-to-day life of Australian soldiers who served during the Vietnamese War. By using super-8 film footage that the soldiers took of themselves, we are taken from training in Australia to the camps in Vietnam where the young men were to confront the terrors of fighting a bitter guerrila war. The super-8 images are ultimately touching because they reveal young boys at the point of losing their innocence. The haunting musical score is by David Bridie and John Phillips of Not Drowning, Waving.
